[h1]The Bazaar is a crazy place[/h1]
[hr][/hr]
The Bazaar is an auto battler, or a hero builder like the game designer would call it, but not like any other game. It has a unique gameplay loop and executes it masterfully, centered around the idea of visiting themed shops and meeting unique characters in different encounters and events to get you ready for a confrontation with a player at the end of each in-game day. The goal is to win as many PvP battles as possible, ending at 10 wins or until you run out of prestige, which I’ll get into later.

[h2]Gameplay and mechanics[/h2]
A genius mechanic of this game is the [b]asynchronous PvP[/b]. You’re not locked in a match with 7 other players for a match like in most auto battlers. This allows you to leave at literally any point during the run without losing any progress, which is amazing if you don’t have the time for a full run but still want to play. The decisions can take any amount of time you want, and the battlers work like this: when the time comes to battle a player, you will face what a real player had on the exact day you’re at: a snapshot of his character at the time, or ghosts as we call them. After you face that ghost, it is removed from the pool and now your ghost substitutes your opponent’s, so someone else will fight the ghost you left.

The essence of the gameplay in The Bazaar is to make the most of the situations you get. This means it’s not possible to always play the same build, which is something I personally love about the game. Because the item pool of each character is quite big you’ll quickly learn that fishing for a specific item is usually a bad idea. The diversity of vendors and events will make you think on your feet and assemble a set of items that can work now, while still having to plan for future days.

There are currently 6 characters, each with their pool of over 100 different items. A character can get items from another character through some rare vendors and encounters, but usually get their own items on display at regular vendors, 3 at a time and grouped by category. Items can activate on a cooldown or be passive, and have tons of different uses. There are damage items, healing, shielding, damage over time inflicting, items which destroy others and so on. They vary in size and you’ll have a board of 10 slots to fill with them.

Tying the item mechanic to the different characters, the win condition for a battle is to survive, not necessarily beat the opponent, which is really flavorful because the game can have characters that are traders, chefs, engineers and not only characters that can fight and their items reflect this. For example, the merchant-like character has properties which can shield and heal them, and you can win a run without ever dishing out a single point of damage.

Each in-game day has 6 hours, with the battle against another player being the last hour. The third hour is always a battle with a themed character from the bazaar, so it’s known exactly what items, skills and general difficulty it is. You get three choices of NPC characters to battle with varying experience and gold rewards based on its difficulty and since you get one of their items or skills if you defeat them, you’ve got to choose your opponent wisely.

Prestige basically means how many losses you can withstand in a run. It starts at 20 and each loss against a player costs a point multiplied by the day you lost in, meaning early losses aren’t that costly to the Prestige meter. There’s even a sweet comeback mechanic that when any player would run out of prestige, they get a second chance with game changing upgrades to choose from, so even a bad run can be turned around with this second wind.

[h2]Art and World Building[/h2]
I’m constantly surprised by the high quality of the art assets, they’re easily as good as the best in class, like you would expect from a AAA game. I would extend this compliment to world building too. The characters you’ll find have cool voice lines, themed items, interesting related skills and feel very natural in the world of The Bazaar.

There are cosmetics like different boards, money stashes, alternate character arts and so on. Every item also has a shiny version of it. All of these are obtainable by just playing the game.

There are plenty of details for immersion or just some extra fun, like elaborate animations for some key items with huge effects like The Boulder or like having one of your items change the outcome of an event. It’s full of flavor like that, enhancing the experience quite a lot.

[h2]The ghosts of the past[/h2]
The Bazaar had some stumbles along the way with monetization, bad standalone launcher before Steam, having no patch notes at all, performance issues and some shockingly amateur development work.

About monetization, although I would like for the game to have some sort of free to try angle, like having only one character available, maybe with some other limitations, it’s on the best spot it’s ever been for the current players. It might be a little expensive, but regional pricing on Steam got us covered. My only fear is it’ll be harder to attract new players, since the studio also does no marketing at all for it. After seeing the studio shooting themselves in the foot with pay to win mechanics, I’m glad to say it’s in the past now.

Performance seems to be much more stable on Steam without their custom launcher, with noticeable server improvements too. Communication also greatly improved from the early launch days, back to the transparency of pre-release. My complaints with the development is specifically about the implementation of the item changes, which commonly had problems like enchants not being updated to the point of making some enchants literally useless or not testing some skills that were not working at all. It happened multiple times per patch, but it seems that they are getting a grip on it and not repeating these rookie mistakes.

All in all, it was a pretty rocky road and while there are still things that should be worked on like the UI, it seems most of these problems are behind us now.

[h2]My Experience[/h2]
I have around 400 hours of playtime using their own launcher in addition to the Steam hours. I like to visit this game regularly, usually a match every day, and never get bored of it. Even after all this time I constantly get surprised by how endless the build possibilities are. Sometimes you’ll see an opponent with something you’d never have thought of, but it’s not too rare you can assemble boards like these too, because of how many events and opportunities there are. This is why I play the game, it fills me with joy creating a build that’s really hard to replicate because of a series of specific outcomes from the many events I encountered.

I can’t overstate this enough, because it’s a much bigger deal than it might seem, but [b]even the losses are very fun[/b]. I think I only had a couple of runs that I didn’t have fun, maybe because I didn’t adapt too well or got really unlucky with offerings and matchups. I think there are two big factors that contribute to this, which are the comeback mechanic I explained before and also the win “goals”. If you win 10 battles against players, that’s it, you’ve got a gold win if you lost some prestige along the way or a diamond win if you didn’t lose any. But there are other breakpoints too, which also give rewards, being the bronze win at 4 and the silver win at 7. Obviously I’ll always shoot for the 10 wins, and it requires a lot of skill and a bit of luck to do them consistently, but a silver win never bothered me and felt like a nice goal to have.

After following the game’s development for years, I can definitely say they hit the mark and I have a ton of fun playing this game. Easily one of the best games I’ve played and it’s constantly being improved on. If you ever need to do some shopping, consider coming to The Bazaar.

Really good game, I purchased it recently and have been liking it a lot, it's the funnest rogue-like deck-building auto battler that I've played. It's basically a rogue-like auto-battler that feels a lot like Hearthstone. 

--- What you get from your purchase and payment model ---

You get 3 characters with the base-game, and any additional character costs money in the form of a DLC that cost $20 each. You have access to the ranked and normal games immediately for the 3 base characters. 

--- Gameplay ---

Each run, the progression is about getting as much wins as possible, with 10 at maximum. This is also signified as each 'day', whether you win or lose, you progress to the next day. At the beginning of each day on your run, you have two randomized options (such as a skill, free card (item), or access to a shop), then a monster fight, then two more randomized options again, before you're put forward to face an actual player and the first 'day' ends. The players are just decks of people who started a run recently also, but you're not fighting against the player live, I believe it just takes the deck of a player that they made on the same 'day' as you.

You have a lot of variety with your gameplay and a ton you can be creative with, because you often get access to other players cards too and you can make interesting combos.

High learning curve - this game has a much higher learning curve than Hearthstone imo (unless you play Wild ofc). You have to remember a ton of cards because they are randomized, you can get a card from your character, a neutral card OR a card from another character too. So keeping in mind all of those can be tough. It's easy to pick up but hard to master. 

--- Visuals and Sound ---

Nothing much more to say except that this game's graphics are great. It has Hearthstone inspired graphics, but better. You can still click around and interact with the map, which I like. The art on the cards is amazing. The sounds are good, music is pretty cozy too.

--- Rewards ---

All rewards you will get from your runs are just in the form of cosmetics. I do think that the cosmetics are really good in this game, there's a ton you can mess with and you get a lot of cosmetics for free.

--- My issues ---

I still like this game, but it does have it's plethora of issues.

1. The game is still buggy visually, to the point that there is literally a huge 'report bug' button in your game. But it hasn't bothered me a ton because the visual bugs don't happen that often for me. But if you're someone that expects no visual bugs then it might bother you.

2. New characters are overpowered. 

Same as other people said, if you're playing ranked upon release of a new character, and you're playing with a base character forget it, you're getting stomped. Such as the case with Jules right now. DON'T buy this game if you think that you can be on fair grounds competitively with just the base game. You will get stomped by the new character release. Not saying you can't compete with the base characters but.. you will be the underdog. 

3. Payment model. 

I don't mind it, as long as they put the DLCs on discount every so often.. because $20 permanently for a character seems excessive. $10 is still a lot but I'd buy one here and there if there's a discount, since I know this is what supports the devs too. 

But I don't think it makes sense that 'The Bazaar' button is just ONE cosmetic item per day, that you can spend with the in game currency. What if you're not playing every day and miss it? Why not make the payment model more about cosmetics and have the big in your face "The Bazaar" (literally called after the game) button be a catalog of items? 

Instead, cosmetics are given out a ton freely for playing games. Which I like but, if I had to choose between having access to all characters upon buying the game versus not having as many cosmetics, I'd choose the first option.

4. Last but not least, there's no speed up button. If you're playing a few runs in a row, it feels tedious having to wait through the fight with the monsters each time. I think it makes sense to add a game speed up button for the monster fights, and leave it off for the player fights. But even there I see why not add one for the player fights.

As someone who enjoyed both Hearthstone’s rogue-lite PvE mode (Solo Adventures) and its auto-chess-style PvP mode (Battlegrounds), I found this game’s rogue-lite structure to be a very refreshing experience. It successfully captures the strengths of both systems while offering its own unique take as a single-player board-game-like roguelite. Overall, I had a great time playing it. However, the late-game phase—around Days 7–8—starts to feel overly monotonous. This seems largely due to the limited opportunities to purchase items, which in turn narrows the range of actions available to the player. I hope the developers consider ways to diversify gameplay after Day 6, such as increasing bag size or item-purchase opportunities.

After Day 7, the available choices become almost predetermined, shifting the gameplay from strategic decision-making to simply executing a fixed sequence of steps. Currently, both the field and the bag have 10 slots, which is just enough to manage two decks: one structured deck for field battles and a set of items in the bag for preparing a secondary build. However, the chances to purchase items are very limited. Even if the player encounters every merchant and uses all reroll opportunities, the maximum is roughly 4 shops × 2 pages = 8 item pages. As a result, the gameplay from Day 7 onward mostly becomes checking shop inventories for field-deck upgrades or for items that support an alternative build stored in the bag. In a roguelite—where variability is a core source of fun—this repetitive and highly deterministic loop becomes a significant drawback.

I believe the experience could be improved by expanding players’ strategic flexibility in the late game. For example, starting from Day 8, increasing the bag size to 15 slots or allowing players to spend large amounts of leftover gold for up to three additional rerolls would meaningfully increase item-purchase opportunities. This would make it viable to manage up to three decks and switch between them depending on the situation, resulting in far more dynamic and engaging gameplay.

Dear Developers,

I think you know how unique this game is. From the very beginning, it promised something many of us hoped and dreamed for. And now, after a year of pathfinding, you have found the right direction—finally delivering on those promises.

So what makes this game special?

This game is a live-service game, and yet it is not.

This game is a competitive game, and yet it is not.

This game looks like one where you have to grind (reward chests, daily quests, weekly quests, etc.), but in reality, you don’t.

This game could easily have demanded constant play in order to “keep up with the meta,” but it doesn’t.

This game could have been ruined by endless changes to characters, purchasable cards, season passes, and all that, but it is not.

This game could have created FOMO with seasonal rewards, but it does not.

It is the perfect co-op game—yet it doesn’t even have a co-op tag.

The Bazaar takes the best aspects of live-service and competitive gaming, without the downsides.
You are never angry when you lose, and there is no toxicity from opponents.
The greatest advantage of a live-service game is expansion—and, in the best case, doing so without breaking the core game.

In other words: this game has everything it needs to become a timeless classic, with the added bonus of a new hero now and then.

I believe The Bazaar can be compared to single-player games just as much as to online titles.
I love classics like Diablo 2, Heroes 3, and my favorite single player Steam game: American Truck Simulator. ATS is a perfect example of expanding a game the right way: every new DLC simply adds more content while leaving the core formula untouched.

In contrast to what seems to be the general philosophy of modern live-service games, I think change is not always good.
As a League of Legends beta player, whenever I think of that game, I can’t help but say: “Look how they massacred my boy.”
I truly believe The Bazaar can be a game where you don’t have to relearn everything after a long break. 

The Bazaar is a great co-op game too.
The game gives me the exact same feeling I had 20 years ago, sitting in front of the same CRT monitor with a friend, calculating whether we should attack that stack of black dragons. It is the perfect old-school co-op experience.

The joy is in making those decisions—and making those decisions together.

Here’s some good news for anyone over the age of 16:
This is a puzzle game, so you don’t need any dexterity at all. No hand-eye coordination, no fast reactions—none of that nonsense. And yet you are on the edge of your seat every single minute.

So, putting it all together:

The Bazaar is a near-perfect game.
It’s essentially a single-player experience, yet with the excitement of knowing that another person crafted the enemy you face with their wit and luck. The fact that you can quit anytime is almost too good to be true (although it does require willpower).
The endless combinations and possibilities mean unlimited replayability.

Whenever I think I’m not in the mood to play, or I’m unsure which hero to choose, that feeling disappears the moment I face my first decision. From that point on, the game pulls me in completely. I forget everything: past runs, future hopes—everything. I’m in a state of flow, building the next best character ever with full attention, with not a single trace of boredom.
I don’t know many PC or tabletop games that can do this to me.

With all that said, I’m baffled by the negative reviews aimed at pricing. Let me return to the beginning and say that the monetization model The Bazaar has right now is the best thing that could have happened to it.
You pay a little, and then you can play unlimited games with the exact same opportunities as everyone else. If you think the newest character is overpowered, then buy it, try it—and see how many older heroes will still kick your butt with their game-breaking combos.

Because at the end of the day, with a bit of luck, you can create a brilliant combo with any hero and watch it unfold with glee.

If you're looking for a casual autobattler to dip into every now and then, I wouldn't really recommend The Bazaar. 

While the game has potential, it suffers from drastic patch-to-patch changes that make it hard to keep up unless you're deeply invested. These updates can be exciting for hardcore players or stream viewers who enjoy dissecting meta shifts, but for the average player, it can feel overwhelming and inconsistent.

The frequent changes are great if you have plenty of time to watch streams, read guides, or follow external websites. But if you're just looking for a pick-up-and-play experience, this isn't it.

Regarding the monetization, there's been a lot of controversy. Some reviewers ask others to ignore it, claiming it's been fixed. That is only partially true. Yes, the developers made major changes after backlash, including removing the paid season pass and making expansion packs free to earn. However, the game has shifted monetization models multiple times --> from free-to-play to a $45 premium version, with additional heroes costing $20 each. That kind of volatility makes it hard to trust they won’t change things again.

Moderation of criticism has also been heavy-handed, so I wouldn’t recommend going to their Discord to voice concerns.

There are also design decisions that feel anti-player. For example, you can't fast-forward fights you already know the outcome of. The devs have stated this is intentional, to make the game more spectator-friendly for platforms like YouTube and Twitch... While that might benefit streamers, it’s frustrating for regular players who just want smoother gameplay.

Again, their choice, but it’s one that prioritizes streaming optics over user experience.

In summary: It’s not for everyone, but I’m sure there’s a dedicated niche out there that genuinely enjoys it. Proceed with caution.

Played this A LOT before it came to steam. The devs couldn't figure out a way to do this game's monetization and switched it up a bunch of times before they apparently settled on this and released it here.

The game is quite fun. It's a fairly unique autobattler, each character feels very distinct from one another and there's tremendous build variety. The production value is also through the roof and everything looks pretty. Those are the positives.

The negative aspects of the bazaar are what had me stop playing. 

First off, I'll come back to the monetization: What they settled on is terrible for the game imo. You can buy the base game with 3 characters, and each new character costs the full base price of the game, so you'd have to pay 4x the base cost to get all the characters, and this is the only way to acquire them, with cosmetics being what players can get by playing the game (but those can also be purchased using real money, of course). The initial cost stops new players from trying out the game (which has a fairly steep learning curve), since it requires an upfront payment with no way to even check out if one enjoys it via a demo or free trial. It alienates potential new players, which to me drastically reduces the game's reach and general sentiment. Finally, I believe not having all the characters to play around with makes learning the game more difficult, as every character explores different aspects of the game, which would also teach how to make builds that more generally succeed against the builds other characters may create, if one had the opportunity to even try other characters out without having to shell out more money.

Moving on to the gameplay, I feel the game doesn't care one bit about the player's time, with drawn out animations and long transitions, and no way to speed up fights (which admittedly feel pretty good to watch regardless). On top of that, despite the game's good looks, everything feels janky and slow to move around. Just interfacing with the game feels like I'm fighting against a lack of polish and the fact that every single action has to be authenticated server-side. Things snap where I don't want them to, buttons aren't as responsive as they should be, and every run has a slight feeling that I'm wasting my time, even after I got more used to the game's needlessly slow pace. Balance never felt too off, although some decisions made by the devs over the course of the game's updates were just absolutely puzzling, since the entire community could, at just a glance, tell what was broken and what was unusably nerfed.

I had a great time with the bazaar, but as time went on the people behind it showed time and time again they care more about making money and censoring criticism, than making an actually good and accessible game beyond all the beautiful art and animations. They even had plans to have an NFT-like in-game trade market at some point... it got scratched but I think it's something important to point out.

I believe there are plenty other autobattlers out there that are just as fun, if not more, that also respect one's time and money. So given the issues I take with both the game and the way the team managed things, I can't recommend this in good faith.
